                    <gmd:citedResponsibleParty>
                        <gmd:CI_ResponsibleParty>

                            <gmd:role>

                    </gmd:citedResponsibleParty>
                    
                    <gmd:citedResponsibleParty>

                                <gco:CharacterString>River Institute</gco:CharacterString>
                            </gmd:organisationName>
                            <gmd:role>
                                <gmd:CI_RoleCode
                                        codeList="https://schemas.isotc211.org/19115/-3/cit/1.0/codelists.xml#CI_RoleCode"

                    </gmd:citedResponsibleParty>
                </gmd:CI_Citation>
            </gmd:citation>
            <gmd:abstract>
                <gco:CharacterString>The Great River Rapport is a community-engaged, science-based ecosystem health report for the Upper St. Lawrence River, founded in partnership with the Mohawk Council of Akwesasne. The Great River Rapport uses advanced statistical methods, including complex modelling, to address community-driven research questions by integrating and analyzing large datasets from a variety of sources, including government, academic, private-sector, and open source/citizen science platforms. The project also promotes tech-based initiatives, including community science and stewardship apps, and employs a variety of digital and multi-media communications technologies, such as interactive online workshops, videos, infographics, and professional design expertise, to effectively translate and disseminate scientific and technical information to relevant groups and individuals.  In promoting community science initiatives, the project has launched a Water Ranger kit lending program for the community to borrow kits free of charge to learn about water quality, connect with their local waterways, and contribute valuable water quality data.</gco:CharacterString>
            </gmd:abstract>
            <gmd:credit gco:nilReason="missing"/>

            <gmd:status>

            </gmd:descriptiveKeywords>

                    </gmd:useLimitation>
                    
                    
                    <gmd:useLimitation>
                        <gco:CharacterString>Water Quality data is contributed by a variety of community scientists, including River Institute employees, summer students, and community volunteers. All participants take part in Water Rangers training online prior to testing water.</gco:CharacterString>
                    </gmd:useLimitation>
                    
                </gmd:MD_LegalConstraints>
            </gmd:resourceConstraints>

            </gmd:language>

            </gmd:topicCategory>

                            </gmd:eastBoundLongitude>

                                    <gml:beginPosition>2018-06-22T19:50:00+00:00</gml:beginPosition>
                                    <gml:endPosition>2023-11-24T12:48:00+00:00</gml:endPosition>
                                </gml:TimePeriod>

                        </gmd:EX_TemporalExtent>

license_title: Open Data Commons Public Domain Dedication and Licence 1.0
name: 10-25976-ucia-o838
notes: The Great River Rapport is a community-engaged, science-based ecosystem health report for the Upper St. Lawrence River, founded in partnership with the Mohawk Council of Akwesasne. The Great River Rapport uses advanced statistical methods, including complex modelling, to address community-driven research questions by integrating and analyzing large datasets from a variety of sources, including government, academic, private-sector, and open source/citizen science platforms. The project also promotes tech-based initiatives, including community science and stewardship apps, and employs a variety of digital and multi-media communications technologies, such as interactive online workshops, videos, infographics, and professional design expertise, to effectively translate and disseminate scientific and technical information to relevant groups and individuals.  In promoting community science initiatives, the project has launched a Water Ranger kit lending program for the community to borrow kits free of charge to learn about water quality, connect with their local waterways, and contribute valuable water quality data.

notes_translated.en: The Great River Rapport is a community-engaged, science-based ecosystem health report for the Upper St. Lawrence River, founded in partnership with the Mohawk Council of Akwesasne. The Great River Rapport uses advanced statistical methods, including complex modelling, to address community-driven research questions by integrating and analyzing large datasets from a variety of sources, including government, academic, private-sector, and open source/citizen science platforms. The project also promotes tech-based initiatives, including community science and stewardship apps, and employs a variety of digital and multi-media communications technologies, such as interactive online workshops, videos, infographics, and professional design expertise, to effectively translate and disseminate scientific and technical information to relevant groups and individuals.  In promoting community science initiatives, the project has launched a Water Ranger kit lending program for the community to borrow kits free of charge to learn about water quality, connect with their local waterways, and contribute valuable water quality data.
notes_translated.fr: Le Great River Rapport est un rapport sur la santé des écosystèmes du Haut-Saint-Laurent, fondé sur la communauté et fondé sur la science, créé en partenariat avec le Conseil des Mohawks d'Akwesasne. Le Great River Rapport utilise des méthodes statistiques avancées, y compris la modélisation complexe, pour répondre à des questions de recherche communautaires en intégrant et en analysant de grands ensembles de données provenant de diverses sources, notamment des plateformes gouvernementales, universitaires, du secteur privé et open source/science citoyenne. Le projet promeut également des initiatives basées sur la technologie, notamment des applications de science communautaire et de gestion, et utilise diverses technologies de communication numériques et multimédias, telles que des ateliers interactifs en ligne, des vidéos, des infographies et une expertise professionnelle en conception, afin de traduire et de diffuser efficacement les informations scientifiques et techniques aux groupes et individus concernés. Afin de promouvoir les initiatives scientifiques communautaires, le projet a lancé un programme de prêt de kits Water Ranger permettant à la communauté d'emprunter des kits gratuitement pour en savoir plus sur la qualité de l'eau, se connecter à ses cours d'eau locaux et fournir des données précieuses sur la qualité de l'eau.

notes_translation_method.fr: Description text translated using the Amazon translate service / texte traduit à l'aide du service Amazon translate

description_translated.en: DataStream is an open access platform for sharing water and sediment quality data.
description_translated.fr: DataStream est une plateforme en libre accès pour partager des données sur la qualité de l'eau et des sédiments.

title: Great River Rapport Water Quality Data - Water Rangers

title_translated.fr: Données sur la qualité de l'eau du Great River Rapport - Water Rangers
